title.value: DynGFN: Towards Bayesian Inference of Gene Regulatory Networks with GFlowNets
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as indicated at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: DynGFN: Towards Bayesian Inference of Gene Regulatory Networks with GFlowNets

extractions.description: The paper introduces DynGFN, a novel framework leveraging Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) for Bayesian inference of Gene Regulatory Networks (GRNs) particularly focusing on modelling uncertainty in cyclic gene regulation structures from noisy observational data.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical evaluations and experiments on synthetic and real biological data to validate the proposed DynGFN framework.
type.quote: We showcase the use of DynGFN on a real biological system using single-cell RNA-velocity data for learning posteriors of GRNs.

name.justification: The primary research field is Computational Biology, as the paper's main focus is on inferring gene regulatory networks using machine learning techniques.
name.quote: One of the grand challenges of cell biology is inferring the gene regulatory network (GRN)...

name.justification: Part of the research involves developing a Bayesian inference framework to capture the uncertainty in GRN structures.
name.quote: We develop a novel framework for Bayesian structure learning under the lens of dynamical system identification for modelling complex posteriors over cyclic graphs.

name.justification: The main application of the proposed framework is the inference of gene regulatory networks.
name.quote: We showcase the use of DynGFN on a real biological system using single-cell RNA-velocity data for learning posteriors of GRNs.

name.justification: The main model proposed in the paper is DynGFN, tailored for Bayesian dynamic structure learning.
name.quote: We design a novel GFlowNet architecture, Dynamic GFlowNet (DynGFN), tailored for modelling posteriors over cyclic structures.

is_contributed.justification: DynGFN is the primary contribution introduced by the authors.
is_contributed.quote: We design a novel GFlowNet architecture, Dynamic GFlowNet (DynGFN), tailored for modelling posteriors over cyclic structures.

is_executed.justification: The model was implemented and tested in the experiments described in the paper.
is_executed.quote: We empirically evaluated DynGFN on synthetic dynamic data designed to induce highly multimodal posteriors over graphs.

is_compared.justification: The performance of DynGFN was compared with baseline models in the empirical studies.
is_compared.quote: We find that ℓ-DynGFN and h-DynGFN yield low KL and moderate Bayes-SHD.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The model was introduced in this paper and is not based on a previous work.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We design a novel GFlowNet architecture, Dynamic GFlowNet (DynGFN), tailored for modelling posteriors over cyclic structures.

name.justification: BCD-Nets is one of the baseline models compared against DynGFN in the experiments.
name.quote: We apply versions of DiBS and BCD-Nets such that they are applicable in our Bayesian dynamic structure learning framework.

is_contributed.justification: BCD-Nets is an existing model used for comparison purposes in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We apply versions of DiBS and BCD-Nets such that they are applicable in our Bayesian dynamic structure learning framework.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed as part of the experimental comparisons with DynGFN.
is_executed.quote: We compare to Bayesian methods that can also accomplish this task, i.e. versions of BCD-Nets [11] and DiBS [32].

is_compared.justification: The performance of BCD-Nets was compared with DynGFN in the empirical studies.
is_compared.quote: Since our primary objective is to learn Bayesian posteriors over discrete structure G, we compare to Bayesian methods that can also accomplish this task, i.e. versions of BCD-Nets [11] and DiBS [32].

referenced_paper_title.value: BCD Nets: Scalable Variational Approaches for Bayesian Causal Discovery
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the original paper where BCD-Nets was introduced.

name.justification: NeuralODEs is mentioned as a model in related work for structure learning from dynamics.
name.quote: Recent works in this direction based on NeuralODEs [10] propose a single explanatory structure [50, 6, 1, 2].

is_contributed.justification: NeuralODEs is an existing model mentioned in the related work, not a focus of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Recent works in this direction based on NeuralODEs [10] propose a single explanatory structure [50, 6, 1, 2].

is_executed.justification: NeuralODEs were referenced but not executed as part of this paper's experiments.
is_executed.quote: Recent works in this direction based on NeuralODEs [10] propose a single explanatory structure [50, 6, 1, 2].

is_compared.justification: NeuralODEs is referenced in the context of related work, but its performance is not empirically compared with DynGFN.

name.justification: NOTEARS is mentioned as a model for learning acyclic dependencies from observational data.
name.quote: NOTEARS is a score-based approach that uses time-series to learn structure [40].

is_contributed.justification: NOTEARS is an existing model mentioned in the context of related work.
is_contributed.quote: NOTEARS is a score-based approach that uses time-series to learn structure [40].

is_executed.justification: NOTEARS was executed as part of the toy example comparisons.
is_executed.quote: In this example we compare NOTEARS and DynGFN for learning acyclic and cyclic dependencies from observational data.

is_compared.justification: The performance of NOTEARS was compared with DynGFN in the toy example.
is_compared.quote: In this example we compare NOTEARS and DynGFN for learning acyclic and cyclic dependencies from observational data.

name.justification: Single-cell RNA-velocity data was used in the experiments to showcase DynGFN's application to real biological systems.

referenced_paper_title.value: RNA velocity of single cells. Nature, 560, 2018.
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper where RNA velocity methods for single cells were discussed.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We leverage the fact that we can estimate the rate of change of a gene’s expression (velocity) with RNA velocity methods [9].
